Computer_Science_132_r.News Finding: 87 percent of people said answering a call was rarely or never acceptable in business meetings.
Computer_Science_132_r.Paper Finding: Roughly 71% of the professionals said they would not make a call or take a call during a meeting.
Computer_Science_132_r.News Context:
Among their findings:

Three out of four people -- 76 percent -- said checking texts or emails was unacceptable behavior in business meetings. 87 percent of people said answering a call was rarely or never acceptable in business meetings. Even at more informal business lunches, the majority of people thought writing a text message is rude -- 66 percent said writing or sending a text message is inappropriate.
Computer_Science_132_r.Paper Context: Interestingly, just 24% thought using a laptop in a meeting was not appropriate. Roughly 71% of the professionals said they would not make a call or take a call during a meeting. Approximately 63% said that they would not text message during meetings.
Computer_Science_132_r.text: ['Finding: 87 percent of people said answering a call was rarely or never acceptable in business meetings.']
Computer_Science_132_r.displayed_text: Finding: 87 percent of people said answering a call was rarely or never acceptable in business meetings.

Computer_Science_tweet_280_r.News Finding: People laugh more and are happier in face-to-face or video conferencing meetings - less so in teleconf  #eventprofs
Computer_Science_tweet_280_r.Paper Finding: Whilst the duration of the interaction for FTF positively predicted happiness, there was no effect of duration on happiness for the other modes, including those CMC modes that included auditory cues (Skype and telephone).
Computer_Science_tweet_280_r.News Context: People laugh more and are happier in face-to-face or video conferencing meetings - less so in teleconf  #eventprofs
Computer_Science_tweet_280_r.Paper Context: Hypothesis 1 was only partially supported. Whilst the duration of the interaction for FTF positively predicted happiness, there was no effect of duration on happiness for the other modes, including those CMC modes that included auditory cues (Skype and telephone). Results showed robust support for Hypothesis 2.

Computer_Science_tweet_1_r.News Finding: 3-D printing was successfully used to create a model of the prostate with the physical properties of prostate tissue.
Computer_Science_tweet_1_r.Paper Finding: The 3D printed prostate model demonstrated high fidelity with patient organ and tissue in ana tomical, static and dynamic mechanical, hardness, and optical properties.
Computer_Science_tweet_1_r.News Context: 3-D printing was successfully used to create a model of the prostate with the physical properties of prostate tissue.
Computer_Science_tweet_1_r.Paper Context: In summary, we have designed and developed a series of novel methodologies and customized inks for fabricating a 3D printed prostate model with physical properties of tissue and integrated sensing capabilities that can be used for quantitative, advanced surgical rehearsal. The 3D printed prostate model demonstrated high fidelity with patient organ and tissue in ana tomical, static and dynamic mechanical, hardness, and optical properties. Therefore, the prostate model can aid medical pro fessionals to perform more effective preoperative planning and rehearsal and predict organ physical behavior more accurately.
Computer_Science_tweet_1_r.text: ['Finding: 3-D printing was successfully used to create a model of the prostate with the physical properties of prostate tissue. ']
Computer_Science_tweet_1_r.displayed_text: Finding: 3-D printing was successfully used to create a model of the prostate with the physical properties of prostate tissue.

Computer_Science_tweet_17_r.News Finding: An optical version of a brain-inspired neurosynaptic system, using wavelength division multiplexing techniques, is presented that is capable of supervised and unsupervised learning. #deeplearning
Computer_Science_tweet_17_r.Paper Finding: The neurosynaptic system described so far provides the basic structure needed for supervised learning tasks, where the weights of the inputs are set by an external supervisor.
Computer_Science_tweet_17_r.News Context: An optical version of a brain-inspired neurosynaptic system, using wavelength division multiplexing techniques, is presented that is capable of supervised and unsupervised learning. #deeplearning
Computer_Science_tweet_17_r.Paper Context: 1c , serves as a building block in layered photonic networks (described below) suited to the scalable implementation of neurosynaptic systems. The neurosynaptic system described so far provides the basic structure needed for supervised learning tasks, where the weights of the inputs are set by an external supervisor. Probe pulses sent to the waveguide lying below the neuronal ring resonator either couple to it or generate an output spike depending, as described previously, on whether the neuronal PCM cell is in the crystalline or amorphous state.

Computer_Science_tweet_17_r.displayed_text: Finding: An optical version of a brain-inspired neurosynaptic system, using wavelength division multiplexing techniques, is presented that is capable of supervised and unsupervised learning. #deeplearning

Computer_Science_tweet_32_r.News Finding: Read @username study in @username about big data stored in a drop of DNA:
Computer_Science_tweet_32_r.Paper Finding: DNA is an attractive medium to store digital information.
Computer_Science_tweet_32_r.News Context: Read @username study in @username about big data stored in a drop of DNA:
Computer_Science_tweet_32_r.Paper Context: DNA is an attractive medium to store digital information. Finally, we explored the limit of our architecture in terms of bytes per molecule and obtained a perfect retrieval from a density of 215 petabytes per gram of DNA, orders of magnitude higher than previous reports. DNA is an excellent medium for data storage, owing to its demonstrated information density of petabytes of data per gram, high durability, and evolutionarily optimized machinery to faithfully replicate this information (1, 2).
